bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J. O. Gawne, Mrs. Gawne, and Mr. and Mrs. John M. Lazear, February 7, 1955

div1.p: Hench gives explicit instructions on the procedures and protocol for the Lazear family in their visit to Cuba in order to honor Jesse Lazear and Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J. O. Gawne, Mrs. Gawne, and Mr. and Mrs. John M. Lazear, February 7, 1955
div1.opener:
February 7, 1955
Captain and Mrs. James O. Gawne
Mr. and Mrs. John Lazear
Naples, Florida
Dear Friends:
div1.p:
Please wire me at your earliest convenience your intended date of arrival
at Havana and where you will be staying so that you can be gotten in
touch with and be sure to tell me also how long you expect to stay there
and when you expect to leave. May I suggest that, if possible, your de-
parture be flexible in case any friend of mine and admirer of Doctor
Lazear wants to show you around and in case you want to accept, in other
words, in case you find your visit gets more pleasant and instructive
than you might think.

With regard to your tentative decision to go to the Sevilla Biltmore, may
I suggest that if you are only going to be in Havana a very short time,
such as two days and a night, the Sevilla might be preferable, but if you
are going to be there at least three or four days, and if a very few
dollars more per day is not important, I would urge that you go to the
Nacional. The ladies will like it much better and by taxi it is hardly
more than six or seven minutes downtown. Another point: The Hotel
Nacional is distinctly a better “social address” for our Cuban friends
to reach you at and, most important of all, the Nacional is actually two
miles nearer Camp Lazear and Quemados than is the Sevilla Biltmore. That
is, the Nacional is right between the two main locations you will be
visiting: (a) Downtown Havana and (b) Quemados. The hotel pool, etc., is
magnificent and a delightful place for you to sit and sip, even though
you don't swim.

Undoubtedly, you planned your trip as a private personal one and I strongly
suspect that you may be concerned lest I take you trip too seriously
and complicate it by involving you with obligations but primarily, I
am so very anxious for you to see not just the one place, Camp Lazear,
but the many places related to Doctor Lazear and his American associates,
including the additional bust, painting, etc., of him as described in my
notes. Also, I am quite anxious for you to meet and to be met by a few
special friends by whom the memory of Doctor Lazear is cherished. I have
had two or three nice letters from Dr. Pedro Nogueira, just recovering
from chickenpox. He is very anxious to do whatever he possibly can and
as far as your seeing the proper sights and people is concerned, he is
the main fellow; but I am very anxious for you to meet Tina Rojas and
her companion, Lydia Cabrera, who own the Finca San Jose. I have had
no reply from my letter to them and suspect that they may be away, pos-
sibly back in Europe (they go yearly; I met them in Paris last fall).

Ordinarily they reply promptly, but they might be simply away for a short
time. Be sure to telephone their home (it may be listed in the Quemados
section of the Havana phone book) and if, per chance, you can't reach them,
by all means stop by yourself or have Pedro take you there. You simply
must see the house and grounds. A cousin, Miss Julia Lomas, should be
there and knows all about Doctor Lazear. The ladies will thoroughly enjoy
seeing the inside of this lovely 150-year old Cuban finca or quinta, the
only one remaining in or near Havana. They have made it a veritable museum.
Incidentally if nobody is there but the servants, let them show you around
and if they don't understand English, just write my name on a piece of paper;
they will understand. Also, if Tina offers to send you their car and
chauffeur or any kind of service, by all means accept.

I am so anxious that you not be disappointed by the area in which the little
Camp Lazear Memorial stands. It is surrounded by homes and especially the
disfiguring quarry, but that can't be helped. That is where it happened.
So be it. Please do not be disappointed either by the modesty of the
memorial (by American standards). This is just a beginning, I assure you,
and in Cuba there is being formed “the friends of Camp Lazear,” to be sup-
ported by prominent Cuban-Americans, sparked by Doctor Nogueira and perhaps
a very prominent American woman, Mrs. Louise Smith and two or three very
influential American men. They have kept out of matters until now as the
early planning had to be Cuban, but now these folks will push and may well
complete the unfinished business.

Another point: If you are historically minded and find yourself disturbed
by the extensive restoration of Building No. 1, don't let Pedro know. You
can discuss it with Rojas and Cabrera. We planned an expert reconstruction
to save every possible bit of original wood but that's one thing Pedro
went ahead with, without consulting me. He just couldn't understand the
importance of preserving as much of the original as possible. Therefore,
as I recall it, a generous amount of the present building is of new wood,
although there is still much of the old wood present and Pedro and the
other patrons are very proud of it. We can't let them down.

I hope that you have time to meet Senora Estella Agramonte Rodriguez Leon,
Agramonte's daughter, one of the most alert and intelligent women I have
ever met. She is a wife, mother and teacher and occasionally too busy to
be 100% hospitable but she is charming and I think would feel hurt if she
did not at least see you, perhaps only for a cocktail at the hotel. Her
husband, a former Cuban Army officer, is pleasant but speaks inferior
English, whereas Estella is linguistically perfect. I am taking the
liberty of dropping her a note; also Mrs. John Moran. Her present ad-
dress is B #258 entre 16 y 18, Reparto Almendares, Havana. I do not have
her telephone number. She is shy, lets on she speaks little English, etc.
Perhaps Pedro will have you meet the Mayor of Marianao. If so, please
remember that he unveiled Doctor Lazear's bronze; he wanted that honor.

Now, if you are willing to do the following, please consider it even
though your first inclination may be unfavorable. I think you might make
a ten-strike if you would lay a wreath not only in honor of Doctor Lazear,
but also one in honor of Doctor Finlay. I think it would please the Cubans
no end and would be the finest expression you could give (as representa-
tives of the Lazear family, the only ones who have visited there yet) to
Page 3 February 7, 1955
show your appreciation not only of Doctor Finlay but particularly of what
the Cubans have done for Doctor Lazear. May I suggest the delicate ap-
proach? Captain Gawne might quietly say that, as a family, you would
like to lay a wreath at the Lazear Memorial in front of Doctor Lazear's
profile but that you would very much like to honor Finlay also and would
it be presumptuous or inappropriate if you did this. If not, should the
wreath be laid at Finlay's grave at Colon Cemetery, or beneath Finlay's
bronze at Camp Lazear. If you went out of the way to lay it in Colon
Cemetery, it might be construed as a higher tribute. On the other hand,
you might not want to lay a wreath simply for Doctor Lazear at the Memorial
and might prefer to lay the Finlay wreath there also. I suspect that Pedro
will pick this idea up and carry the ball eagerly and if you need any fur-
ther advice you, Captain Gawne, could simply telephone the naval attache
of the U. S. Embassy or Ambassador Gardner himself. I am anxious of course
that this idea be your own and that they recognize it as such but if you
feel embarrassed, you might quietly use my name with the Ambassador or
attache in any way you wish, saying that Doctor Hench thought so and so.
But use me only to put on me any responsibility you may not want entirely
for yourself. If Pedro does as I suspect he will, suggests that the wreath
be placed semi-publicly in the presence of a photographer and perhaps the
Mayor of Marianao and/or the patrons (there is no occasion for them now to
have anything but a little semi-public wreath-laying), even that would
please them no end. It would show Pedro, the patrons and the Mayor how much
you appreciate what they did for Doctor Lazear and what Finlay did. It
would make for good feelings all around and help those of us, both here
and in Havana, who wish to do more.

If you decide to do the above, may I suggest that you get the flowers at
that lovely flower store halfway down the Prado on the left side, facing
Morro Castle. The name is Milagros Flores and be sure to ask for the
young proprietress. She is a charming youngish woman of 30-some years
who was so wonderful with respect to all the flowers placed at the Camp
Lazear dedication. Her name was Senora Lucilla Schumann and be sure to
give her my best and tell her I sent you. To save money, I suggest the
following: Tell her you want nothing too fancy or expensive (the Cubans
go in for tremendous floral pieces); suggest perhaps $10 as top price for
each of the one or two pieces (if one for Finlay also). She may well do
for you what she did for me. I paid her $10 each and she made tremendous
beautiful floral pieces, “because she wanted to share the honor.” In the
United States they would have cost $100 each and they were very tasteful.

Political and social divisions are more precise in Cuba than here. Doctor
Nogueira is, perhaps, socially quite unimportant and I think Tina and Lydia
consider him rather inconsequential. To them he lacks the finer cultures.
But for ten years he was the only one that really worked for the preserva-
tion of Camp Lazear; all the other Cubans just talked. Pedro acted and
kept at it steadily for ten years, at times in the face of real dis-
couragement. He is 99% responsible for the Camp Lazear Memorial, for the
honors recently paid to relatives by the Cuban government (to Peggy and
Houston) and, above all perhaps, for insisting that the name Camp Lazear
be preserved when other Cubans, even friendly ones, were inclined to call
it the Finlay Memorial. Those of us interested in bringing this project
to a successful conclusion and in fostering Cuban-American harmony owe
him a great debt. If, per chance, you should want to invite his wife to
Page 4 February 7, 1955
the hotel for cocktails or dinner, she would love it but she speaks poor
English, is not easy to talk to and is not a grand lady like Tina or Lydia.
She and Pedro are about in their late 30's or early 40's. He is a very
dynamic physician in and out of politics, known by everybody although of
the opposite party from Batista. And, above all, he produces!

Accept any invitations from Tina or Lydia that you are inclined to accept.
Tina at least is quite wealthy; both are very pro-U.S. and pro-Lazear and
have done much for this whole project but in an entirely different way
and on a different level from Pedro.

The enclosed manuscripts are not for publication nor are they yet in shape
for critical reading by everybody. The manuscript needs a little shift of
emphasis here and there to satisfy all concerned. It would not yet satisfy
Estella Agremonte or Mrs. Moran - not enough yet about their relative.
Therefore I am not sending them copies yet and I suggest that you not show
it to them but you can show anything or everything to Tina, Lydia and
Pedro. They understand informal, incomplete manuscripts.

You will see that I am still uncertain about a few things: (1) The cementery -
we are making headway on its precise location; there are still two rival
spots but they are only 100 or 200 yards apart, and (2) regarding item
10-A, page 1 of the “wanderings” - my positioning of the old Post Hospital
Buildings with respect to the new Cuban Hospital Buildings is the best I
can do myself. I plan to have an architect-friend do a finished job for
me.

Keep the copies of the talk and the geographic locations and the two 1950
maps of Havana (sorry I only marked up one map) but please return all my
photographs, some of them are my only copies. Later I can make copies
of some if you wish.

If you can well do the following for me, I would deeply appreciate it.
(1) Please show Pedro the photographs and maps and comments about the
cemetery and ask him how he is coming along with his own identification.
He has not seen my latest location of it as indicated on these maps.
(2) If time permits, will you get me the present number of old #16 General
Lee Street directly opposite the present #103; also the present number of
Lee's headquarters, if it has a number. (3) Is the new small Lions'
Memorial to Finlay across the Miramar Bridge over the Almendares River
or have I misnamed the bridge? (4) If you visit the Travel Bureau for
other maps and if they have a newer one than the 1950 one, please swipe
one for me. I suggest that you get two or three and mark them up for
other members of the family. (5) Tell Pedro I will send very soon the
data for the “ Friends of Camp Lazear.” I am all for it and will help
aggressively. (6) In particular, would you ask Pedro if he has made
any progress towards getting me the microfilm of Finlay's diaries which
I have been trying to get for five years now. Also ask Tina or Lydia
the same thing, but don't let Pedro know that you made two inquiries or
vice versa as I am having each try to work on this for me. They will
understand fully.
Best wishes for a wonderful time.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH: alc
